item.title: India Ink: India Election Digest: April 30
item.description: A roundup of local election-related news for Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: By SUHASINI RAJ
item.media:credit: Rouf Bhatrouf Bhat/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: An election official checked an electronic voting machine on the eve of voting in Srinagar, Jammu and Kashmir.

item.title: Unrest in Iraq Narrows Odds for Maliki Win
item.description: The prime minister faced a long list of rivals and a longer list of grievances as Iraqis prepared for national elections on Wednesday, their first since the withdrawal of American forces.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By TIM ARANGO and MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:credit: Max Becherer for The New York Times
item.media:description: Many question whether Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki has the votes to win another term.

item.title: World Briefing: Britain Says No Inquiry in 1971 Killings of Belfast Catholics
item.description: The government said Tuesday that it would not order a fact-finding inquiry into the 1971 killing of 10 Belfast Catholics by British troops during a three-day street confrontation, a decision that infuriated relatives of the dead.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: 20 Killed in Southern Yemen as Ground Assault Begins
item.description: The first day of a government ground offensive aimed at dislodging militants from Al Qaeda in southern Yemen led to the deaths of 20 people on Tuesday, mostly Yemeni soldiers, officials said.
item.dc:creator: By SAEED AL BATATI

item.title: World Briefing: Muslim Man Is Beheaded in Central African Republic
item.description: Christian militiamen decapitated a young Muslim man in the capital, Bangui, two days after peacekeepers escorted some of the last remaining Muslims from the city.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Italian Court Says Amanda Knox Killed Roommate Over Argument
item.description: Ms. Knox, an American, spent four years in an Italian prison after a court found that she and her then-boyfriend had murdered Ms. Knox’s roommate, Meredith Kercher, in 2007.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Social Media in Afghanistan Takes On Life of Its Own
item.description: A U.S.-financed network to connect Afghans across forbidding physical and cultural divides still survives three years after American funding ended.
item.dc:creator: By RON NIXON

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: An Alarm Over the Incursion of Foreign Words
item.description: While a language’s absorption of foreign words is often seen as a positive mark of a society’s cosmopolitanism, the reaction in China has been anything but positive – at least according to state media.
item.dc:creator: By AMY QIN
item.media:description: People's Daily has criticized the use of foreign words as damaging the "purity and health" of the Chinese language.

item.title: Milder View of Suspect in U.S. Case on Terror
item.description: Ahmed Abassi, who prosecutors in Manhattan once said had spoken of killing 100,000 people, was offered a plea bargain that could lead to a sentence of six months.
item.dc:creator: By BENJAMIN WEISER

item.title: Jewish Groups Consider Including J Street
item.description: The major coalition of Jewish groups plans to vote on whether to admit the dovish organization J Street, which says it is pro-Israel and pro-peace but has been critical of some Israeli policies.
item.category: Conference of Presidents of Major American Jewish Organizations
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL PAULSON
item.media:description: Jeremy Ben-Ami is president of J Street, a lobbying group based in Washington that calls itself pro-Israel and pro-peace.

item.title: With Peace Talks Off, Netanyahu Looks at Unilateral Moves
item.description: The Israeli prime minister has asked his cabinet to bring forward alternative approaches to the Palestinian conflict, which are likely to include annexing parts of the West Bank or withdrawing from some settlements and shoring up others.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: The Israeli barrier at the Shuafat refugee camp. Withdrawing from or annexing some areas in the West Bank may be considered.

item.title: Pro-Russian Militants Seize More Offices in Eastern Ukraine
item.description: The move came in apparent defiance of the latest Western sanctions, with the European Union adding 15 names to its sanctions list.
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE, ANDREW ROTH and NEIL MacFARQUHAR
item.media:description: The European Union imposed asset freezes and travel bans on 15 Russians and Ukrainians, including Dmitri N. Kozak, a Russian deputy prime minister, seen here in March with President Vladimir V. Putin.

item.title: Pro-Assad Areas Are Attacked in Syria, Pointing to Election Trouble
item.description: The Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons said it was sending an investigative mission to Syria to “establish the facts.”
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD and NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: Preparations for Rio Olympics ‘the Worst,’ Committee Official Says
item.description: Doubts are growing about the city’s ability to get ready for the 2016 Summer Olympics without international help, and officials say there is no Plan B.
item.dc:creator: By TAYLOR BARNES

item.title: Jewish Groups Consider Including J Street, a Critic of Israel
item.description: The major coalition of Jewish groups plans to vote on whether to admit the dovish organization J Street, which says it is pro-Israel and pro-peace but has been critical of some Israeli policies.
item.category: Conference of Presidents of Major American Jewish Organizations
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL PAULSON
item.media:description: Jeremy Ben-Ami is president of J Street, a lobbying group based in Washington that calls itself pro-Israel and pro-peace.

item.title: Moscow Journal: Amid a Revived East-West Chill, Cold War Relics Draw New Interest
item.description: At the Museum of the Cold War, visitors are drawn as much by history as by the sense that current crises have reignited the conflict between East and West.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Igor V. Lavrenchuk, general manager of the Museum of the Cold War, in a conference room designed for the Soviet air force command.

item.title: Vowing Changes, South Korean Leader Apologizes for Ferry Disaster
item.description: Under mounting public pressure over a disaster that left 302 people dead or missing, President Park Geun-hye promised broad reforms.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: President Park Geun-hye, left, paid silent tribute to victims of the sunken ferry Sewol before a cabinet meeting in Seoul on Tuesday.

item.title: Lens Blog: Twenty Years After Apartheid
item.description: Joao Silva came of age as a photographer as his native South Africa was navigating a treacherous path to democracy. Twenty years later, he reflects on what has — and has not — changed.
item.category: The New York Times Lens Blog
item.dc:creator: By JOAO SILVA
item.media:description: Ken Oosterbroek being carried by a fellow photographer, Gary Bernard, after Mr. Oosterbroek was fatally wounded while covering fighting in Tokoza. Greg Marinovich was injured in the fighting. April 18, 1994.

item.title: Ukrainians Turn to the Arts in a Time of Upheaval
item.description: An exhibition at the National Art Museum of Ukraine illustrates how the country has turned to the arts to assert itself.
item.dc:creator: By RACHEL DONADIO

item.title: World Briefing: Blast in Gaza Damages Boat Meant for Protest
item.description: An explosion partially sank a small vessel that Palestinian and foreign activists had planned to use to challenge the Israeli-imposed blockade of the Gaza Strip.
item.dc:creator: By FARES AKRAM

item.title: China’s Ruling Party Expels and Investigates Official
item.description: Party leaders have authorized a criminal investigation of Li Chuncheng, who was close to Zhou Yongkang, the former domestic security chief at the heart of an extensive graft inquiry.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL FORSYTHE and CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: U.S. Announces Actions to Enforce Iran Sanctions
item.description: Eight Chinese companies, a Dubai company and two Dubai-based executives were blacklisted for violating American restrictions on doing business with Iran.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Heroin and Alcohol Led to the Deaths of Ex-SEALs
item.description: Autopsies of Jeffrey Reynolds and Mark Kennedy, the former SEALs, revealed that the men died of respiratory failure and possible heart attacks.
item.dc:creator: By NICHOLAS KULISH

item.title: Europe’s Antitrust Chief Censures Google’s Motorola Mobility Over Key Patents
item.description: The ruling is the strongest statement yet by an antitrust authority against the use of vital patents for mobile digital devices to stymie rivals.
item.dc:creator: By JAMES KANTER and STEVE LOHR
item.media:description: “The so-called smartphone patent wars should not occur at the expense of consumers,” said Joaquín Almunia, the European Union competition commissioner.

item.title: Turks to Seek Extradition of Preacher Living in U.S.
item.description: The Turkish prime minister has accused the Pennsylvania-based preacher’s followers of trying to undermine his government through a corruption investigation.
item.dc:creator: By SEBNEM ARSU and BRIAN KNOWLTON
item.media:description: Fethullah Gulen at his retreat in Saylorsburg, Pa.
